metadata./Title: Dextrocardia with complete atrioventricular block—the right clinical approach to pace a heart on the right hemithorax: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background A heart positioned on the right side of the thorax can be more a complex situation than it seems, 
also the potentially associated congenital cardiopathies are variable. In this regard, patients with dextrocardia present ing with complete atrioventricular block require a thorough anatomical investigation to map the veno-arterial system 
and potential cardiovascular defects before proceeding with a permanent pacing procedure.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 73-year-old Caucasian woman with no significant medical history presented with syncope. Physical examination showed regular heart sounds with an average heart rate of 35–40 beats per minute 
and no other relevant physical findings. Chest X-rays revealed a heart positioned in the right hemithorax. A standard 
electrocardiogram revealed complete atrioventricular block with junctional escape rhythm at nearly 35–40 beats 
per minute. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed a mirror image dextrocardia without any other remark able abnormalities. Venogram performed using the left peripheral cephalic vein showed normal venous return 
into the right atrium positioned on the left side. Surgical intervention consisted of permanent dual chamber pace maker implantation using the left subclavian vein.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion is provided based on the relevant medical literature 
outlining different potential scenarios with associated cardiac and major vessels abnormalities.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion This case highlights an atypical presentation of atrioventricular block in a patient with dextrocardia 
and situs inversus, for whom a successful dual-pacemaker implantation procedure was performed.
Keywords  Dextrocardia, Atrioventricular block, Pacemaker, Imaging, Echocardiography
sections.Introduction:
Introduction
A right positioning of the heart in the thorax can be 
a more complex situation than it seems, and it can be 
related to dextrocardia or dextroversion [1]. While the 
terminology might be confusing, it is important to make 
the difference especially when a cardiac intervention is 
intended. In dextrocardia, the heart apex is pointing to the right while in dextroversion, the heart apex is point ing to the left [1]. Dextroversion is often associated with 
extracardiac anatomical conditions that cause the shift 
of the heart to the midline (mesocardiac) or even to the 
right hemithorax; these conditions encompass right 
pulmonary hypoplasia, left-sided chest lesions such as 
tumors or diaphragmatic hernia, and so on [2].
Dextrocardia prevalence is around 1/12,000, it can be 
isolated (situs solitus) or associated with displacement/
inversion of other organs (situs inversus) [1]. In dextro cardia with situs solitus, the heart is on the right side, 
while other organs are in normal positions; however 
it is a condition often associated with congenital heart 
defects. In dextrocardia with situs inversus, the heart and Open Access

other organs are mirrored, and this condition is associ ated with fewer congenital heart defects [1]. Congenital 
heart defects, mostly encountered in dextrocardia with 
situs solitus, encompass ventricular septal defect, atrial 
septal defect, tricuspid and pulmonic atresia, anomalous 
systemic or pulmonary venous return, and transposition 
of the great arteries, and so on.
In patients presenting with heart rhythm disorder 
requiring electrophysiological study or pacing, it is essen tial to outline and map cardiac and great vessel anatomy 
to facilitate the performance of such invasive or inter ventional procedure given the potential anatomical vari ations in the main vessels (for example, transposition, 
anomalous venous return) and/or associated congenital 
defects (septal defect, tricuspid atresia, and so on) [3]. 
We report on a patient with dextrocardia situs inversus 
who presented with complete atrioventricular block and 
for whom a dual-chamber transvenous pacemaker was 
implanted successfully.
Case presentation
A 73-year-old Caucasian woman presented to the emer gency room for fainting and presyncope. The patient 
had no previous cardiovascular condition notice able, her main risk factors were tobacco smoking, age, 
and a sedentary lifestyle; also, there was no relevant 
medical family history. She was not on any long-term medications, except occasional analgesics for head aches. Physical examination in the emergency room 
revealed muffled heart sounds (left-sided ausculta tion), bradycardia at nearly 35 beats per minute (bpm) 
and blood pressure at 90/50 mmHg. Electrocardiogram 
(EKG; recording electrodes were placed following the 
routine left sided positioning) showed complete atrio ventricular block with escape junctional rhythm at 
nearly 35 bpm (Fig.  1). Chest X-rays showed normal 
lung parenchyma, and right-sided heart with the apex 
pointing to the right evoking dextrocardia. Laboratory
sections.Results:
results were not remarkable.
Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) using the 
Philips iE33 ultrasound system (right-sided approach, 
basically right parasternal long axis and apical) with 
image acquirement while in dorsal supine or right decu bitus positions revealed a mirror image dextrocardia with 
right cavities on the left side and left cavities on the right 
side, normal tricuspid valve, normal cavities dimensions, 
and normal left ventricular function; importantly, there 
were no congenital abnormalities noticeable. There were 
difficulties in assessing pulmonary artery pressure and 
systemic/pulmonary venous return, and three-dimen sional echo imaging was unavailable. Further imaging 
(cardiac tomography, abdominal ultrasound, chest angioMRI) were planned; however, these tests were refused by 
the patient, also she declined transesophageal echo.

The patient’s hemodynamic condition was still criti cal, and after discussing the case within the cardiac team, 
also after explaining to the patient and family the medical 
context and therapeutic options, and after acquiring their 
consent, a dual-chamber pacemaker implantation was 
planned and performed within hours after admission. 
This was performed using left subclavian approach, and 
a contrast injection in the beginning of the procedure 
confirmed a normal systemic venous return into the right 
atrium; the procedure was smooth with no peroperative 
remarkable incident. Figure  2 shows chest X-rays and 
leads positioning postimplantation; also, Fig.  3 showed 
EKG, postimplantation. Following the procedure, the 
patient’s hemodynamic condition improved and became 
asymptomatic, she was discharged within 24 hours after 
admission.
Discussion
This report highlights an exceptional case of com plete atrioventricular block in a patient with mir ror image dextrocardia situs inversus, for whom a 
successful transvenous dual-chamber pacemaker was 
implanted. Although rare, successful endocavitary pac ing for patients with dextrocardia situs inversus has been 
reported [ 4, 5].
A clinical approach and imaging are crucial for accu rate diagnosis, for providing essential anatomical data for 
the operator. The “muffled” cardiac sound reported in the 
emergency room was a consequence of left-sided auscul tation in a patient with dextrocardia, so far undiagnosed 
as such. The main concern to address before engaging in 
implantation procedure is the potential cardiac or major vascular congenital abnormalities, which can make the 
implantation process challenging or impossible.
In cases where anatomical abnormalities make it chal lenging to implant a permanent pacing device via clas sical leads/venous route, leadless pacemaker or even 
epicardial approach might constitute an alternative [3, 6]. 
In all cases, a step-wise approach along with multimodal ity imaging (transesophageal echocardiography cardiac 
computed tomography, cardiac magnetic resonance) can 
provide more safety and anatomical details for the pacing 
procedure [7].
In this patient, chest X-rays showed the dextrocardia 
along with the gastric air bubble on the right side, making 
the diagnosis of dextrocardia situs inversus certain, also 
the transthoracic echocardiography did not show any 
noticeable cardiac abnormalities. In addition, the veno gram allowed a normal systemic venous return. However, 
if the patient were more compliant, more imaging modal ities could have provided better insights into the special 
patient anatomy and potential abnormalities to address 
potential challenges during the implantation procedure.
Limitations
An EKG was not performed with electrodes on the 
right side of the chest given that the diagnosis of dex trocardia was initially unconfirmed. In addition, the 
rapidly deteriorating condition of the patient, with the 
need for immediate intervention, along with the patient 
non-compliance, made the caring team miss this “rightsided” EKG recording. The post-operative EKG was a 
paced rhythm, and we judged unnecessary to show atypi cal QRS axis consecutive to dextrocardia, whether the

recording is made from the standard leads or from the 
right sided leads.
Conclusion
A heart on the right side could indicate either dextro cardia or dextroversion. Dextrocardia can be either situs 
solitus, which is associated with high cardiac structural 
abnormalities, or situs inversus, which has a low rate 
of associated cardiac abnormalities. Cardiac pacing in 
dextrocardia can be challenging, and clearance for the 
pacing procedure should be granted after thorough iden tification of the cardiac and major vascular anatomy. We 
report on a patient with dextrocardia and situs inver sus presenting with complete atrioventricular block, 
for whom a dual-chamber pacemaker was successfully 
implanted via the left subclavian access.
